swot.title: SWOT Analysis
swot.context: SWOT Analysis is a strategic planning framework that evaluates Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats. Developed in the 1960s at Stanford Research Institute, SWOT helps organizations understand their internal capabilities (strengths/weaknesses) and external environment (opportunities/threats) to inform strategic decision-making. This versatile tool is used across business, nonprofit, and government sectors for strategic planning and competitive analysis.
goodUseCases: Business strategy development and market positioning
Product launch planning and competitive analysis
notIdealFor: Highly complex multi-stakeholder problems requiring deep analysis
Quantitative financial analysis or detailed ROI calculations
Problems requiring specialized domain expertise beyond basic strategy
Detailed operational planning with specific timelines and resources

pest.title: PEST Analysis
pest.context: PEST Analysis examines the macro-environmental factors affecting organizations through four key dimensions: Political, Economic, Social, and Technological factors. Created by Harvard professor Francis Aguilar in 1967, PEST provides a framework for scanning the external environment to identify opportunities and threats. Variants include PESTLE (adding Legal and Environmental) and PESTEL. This framework is essential for understanding the broader context in which organizations operate.
goodUseCases: Market entry strategy for new countries or regions
Long-term strategic planning and scenario building
Assessing regulatory and policy impacts on business
Understanding macro trends affecting entire industries
notIdealFor: Internal organizational issues or capability assessment
Detailed competitor analysis or market positioning
Issues requiring technical or specialized domain analysis

ach.title: Analysis of Competing Hypotheses
ach.context: ACH is a structured intelligence analysis methodology developed by CIA analyst Richards J. Heuer Jr. in the 1970s. Unlike conventional analysis that seeks to confirm hypotheses, ACH focuses on disproving them by systematically evaluating evidence against multiple competing explanations. This approach helps overcome confirmation bias and provides more rigorous, defensible conclusions. ACH is now widely used in intelligence, law enforcement, and business analysis.
goodUseCases: Intelligence analysis with multiple possible explanations
Root cause analysis of complex failures or incidents
Due diligence investigations requiring rigorous analysis
notIdealFor: Problems with only one plausible explanation
Issues without sufficient evidence for evaluation
Problems where intuition and experience are primary decision factors

cog.title: Center of Gravity Analysis
cog.description: Systematic COG analysis across DIMEFIL domains with vulnerability scoring and network visualization (JP 3-0 methodology)
cog.context: Center of Gravity (COG) analysis identifies the source of power that provides an entity with its strength, freedom of action, and will to act. Originally a military concept from Carl von Clausewitz's "On War" (1832), COG analysis examines critical capabilities, critical requirements, and critical vulnerabilities to understand what sustains an adversary's power and how it might be neutralized. This framework is widely used in military planning, competitive intelligence, and strategic analysis.
goodUseCases: Military campaign planning and strategy development
Competitive analysis to identify rival vulnerabilities
Understanding adversary or competitor power structures
Business strategy to identify competitive advantages
notIdealFor: Internal organizational development or team building
Customer satisfaction or user experience analysis

operational_context.label: Operational Context
operational_context.description: Define objectives, operating environment, and constraints

centers_of_gravity.label: Centers of Gravity
centers_of_gravity.description: Identify COGs across DIMEFIL domains (Friendly, Adversary, Host Nation)

critical_capabilities.label: Critical Capabilities
critical_capabilities.description: Primary abilities (verbs) that enable the COG to function

critical_requirements.label: Critical Requirements
critical_requirements.description: Essential conditions and resources (nouns) needed for capabilities

critical_vulnerabilities.label: Critical Vulnerabilities
critical_vulnerabilities.description: Weaknesses that can be exploited with Impact/Attainability/Follow-up scoring

network_analysis.label: Network Analysis
network_analysis.description: Visualize relationships and calculate centrality measures

pmesii-pt.title: PMESII-PT Analysis
pmesii-pt.description: Political, Military, Economic, Social, Information, Infrastructure, Physical Environment, Time
pmesii-pt.context: PMESII-PT is a comprehensive operational environment assessment framework used primarily by military and intelligence organizations. It examines Political, Military, Economic, Social, Information, Infrastructure, Physical Environment, and Time factors. Developed by the U.S. military for operational planning, PMESII-PT provides a holistic view of complex operational environments, enabling better understanding of interconnected systems and potential second-order effects of actions.
goodUseCases: Military operational planning and mission analysis
Humanitarian assistance and disaster response planning
Regional analysis for diplomatic or development initiatives
notIdealFor: Simple business decisions or commercial applications
Problems limited to a single domain or sector

dotmlpf.title: DOTMLPF Analysis
dotmlpf.description: Doctrine, Organization, Training, Material, Leadership, Personnel, Facilities
dotmlpf.context: DOTMLPF examines organizational capability through seven domains: Doctrine, Organization, Training, Material, Leadership, Personnel, and Facilities. Developed by the U.S. Department of Defense for capability-based planning, DOTMLPF ensures comprehensive assessment of what's needed to achieve organizational objectives. This framework is particularly valuable for identifying gaps and planning improvements across all aspects of organizational capability.
goodUseCases: Military capability development and gap analysis
notIdealFor: Strategic positioning or business model innovation

dime.title: DIME Framework
dime.context: DIME analyzes instruments of national power through four categories: Diplomatic, Information, Military, and Economic. Used extensively in national security and foreign policy analysis, DIME helps evaluate how nations or actors employ different forms of power to achieve objectives. This framework is essential for understanding statecraft, influence operations, and strategic competition in the international arena.
goodUseCases: Information operations and influence campaign analysis
notIdealFor: Commercial business strategy without geopolitical context

stakeholder.title: Stakeholder Analysis
stakeholder.description: Power/Interest Matrix - Comprehensive stakeholder mapping and engagement planning
stakeholder.context: Stakeholder Analysis identifies and assesses individuals, groups, or organizations that affect or are affected by a project, policy, or decision. By mapping stakeholders based on their power and interest, this framework helps prioritize engagement strategies and manage relationships effectively. Originally developed in business management, stakeholder analysis is now used across project management, policy development, and change management initiatives.
goodUseCases: Project planning and stakeholder engagement strategy

high_power_high_interest.label: Key Players
high_power_high_interest.description: High Power, High Interest - Manage Closely: Engage actively, involve in decisions, build strong relationships

high_power_low_interest.label: Keep Satisfied
high_power_low_interest.description: High Power, Low Interest - Keep Satisfied: Regular updates, ensure concerns addressed, maintain goodwill

low_power_high_interest.label: Keep Informed
low_power_high_interest.description: Low Power, High Interest - Keep Informed: Regular communication, leverage as advocates, consult on issues

low_power_low_interest.label: Monitor
low_power_low_interest.description: Low Power, Low Interest - Monitor: Minimal effort, periodic updates, watch for changes in status

deception.title: Deception Detection (SATS)
deception.description: CIA Structured Analytic Techniques for detecting deception - based on Richards J. Heuer Jr. methodology
deception.context: The CIA's Structured Analytic Techniques for Deception Detection, based on Richards J. Heuer Jr.'s methodology, provides a systematic approach to identifying potential deception using four key assessments: MOM (Motive, Opportunity, Means), POP (Patterns of Practice), MOSES (My Own Sources), and EVE (Evaluation of Evidence). This framework helps analysts overcome cognitive biases and rigorously evaluate whether information might be deliberately misleading.
goodUseCases: Intelligence analysis of potentially deceptive information
Due diligence for high-stakes business transactions
notIdealFor: Routine information verification without deception risk

scenario.label: Scenario
scenario.description: Describe the information or situation being analyzed for potential deception

mom.label: MOM (Motive, Opportunity, Means)
mom.description: Assess whether the adversary has motive, opportunity, and means to deceive

pop.label: POP (Patterns of Practice)
pop.description: Examine historical deception patterns of this actor

moses.label: MOSES (My Own Sources)
moses.description: Evaluate vulnerability of your information sources to manipulation

eve.label: EVE (Evaluation of Evidence)
eve.description: Assess internal consistency and corroboration of evidence

assessment.label: Overall Assessment
assessment.description: Synthesize findings and determine deception likelihood

behavior.title: Behavior Analysis
behavior.description: Objective documentation of behaviors in specific locations/contexts (based on U.S. Army FM TM 3-53.11)
behavior.context: Behavior Analysis provides objective documentation and analysis of behaviors in specific locations or contexts, based on U.S. Army Field Manual TM 3-53.11. This framework focuses on WHAT behavior occurs, WHERE, WHEN, and HOW, without bias toward any specific target audience. It maps behavior timelines with interactive sequences and forks, identifies environmental factors, documents objective barriers and facilitators, analyzes consequences, and identifies potential target audiences. This analysis serves as the foundation for subsequent target-audience-specific COM-B assessments.
goodUseCases: Objective behavior mapping for public health campaigns
Environmental and contextual analysis of behaviors
Identifying target audiences for behavior change initiatives
Mapping behavior sequences and alternative paths
notIdealFor: Intervention design (use COM-B Analysis with BCW)

basic_info.label: Basic Information
basic_info.description: Define the behavior and context being analyzed (WHAT behavior, WHERE, WHEN)

timeline.label: Behavior Timeline
timeline.description: Document when, where, and how long the behavior occurs (interactive timeline with forks)

environmental_factors.label: Environmental Factors
environmental_factors.description: Physical and environmental context. What infrastructure, resources, and accessibility factors exist?

social_context.label: Social and Cultural Context
social_context.description: Cultural norms, social influences, and community dynamics around this behavior.

consequences.label: Consequences and Outcomes
consequences.description: What happens after someone performs this behavior? Rewards, costs, outcomes.

symbols.label: Symbols and Signals
symbols.description: Visual, auditory, or social cues associated with this behavior.

observed_patterns.label: Observed Patterns
observed_patterns.description: Variations and patterns in how different people perform this behavior.

potential_audiences.label: Potential Target Audiences
potential_audiences.description: Who performs this behavior? Who could but doesn't? Identify audience segments for COM-B Analysis.

comb-analysis.title: COM-B Analysis (Behaviour Change Wheel)
comb-analysis.description: Target-audience-specific assessment using the COM-B model and Behaviour Change Wheel methodology
comb-analysis.context: COM-B Analysis applies the Behaviour Change Wheel methodology (Michie et al., 2011) to assess a SPECIFIC target audience's Capability, Opportunity, and Motivation to perform a defined behavior. This target-audience-specific framework evaluates six COM-B components (Physical/Psychological Capability, Physical/Social Opportunity, Reflective/Automatic Motivation) and automatically generates evidence-based intervention recommendations from 9 intervention functions and 7 policy categories. Each analysis links to an objective Behavior Analysis and focuses on one target audience, enabling multiple COM-B analyses for different audiences performing the same behavior.
goodUseCases: Public health campaign design with specific populations
Military influence operations targeting defined audiences
Organizational change initiatives for employee groups
Health promotion programs for specific communities
Evidence-based intervention selection using BCW methodology
Policy development for behavior change at scale

setup.label: Analysis Setup
setup.description: Link to behavior and define target audience

target_audience.label: Target Audience Definition
target_audience.description: Demographics, psychographics, current relationship to behavior

physical_capability.label: Physical Capability Assessment
physical_capability.description: Does this audience have the physical skills, strength, stamina needed?

psychological_capability.label: Psychological Capability Assessment
psychological_capability.description: Does this audience have the knowledge, cognitive skills, comprehension needed?

physical_opportunity.label: Physical Opportunity Assessment
physical_opportunity.description: Does this audience have access to environmental factors, time, resources, infrastructure?

social_opportunity.label: Social Opportunity Assessment
social_opportunity.description: Do cultural norms, social cues, peer influence support this audience?

reflective_motivation.label: Reflective Motivation Assessment
reflective_motivation.description: Do this audience's beliefs, intentions, goals, identity align with the behavior?

automatic_motivation.label: Automatic Motivation Assessment
automatic_motivation.description: Do this audience's emotions, impulses, habits, desires support the behavior?

contextual_factors.label: Contextual Factors
contextual_factors.description: Environmental, cultural, or situational factors affecting this audience

assumptions.label: Assumptions
assumptions.description: What assumptions were made during this assessment?

limitations.label: Limitations
limitations.description: What are the limitations of this analysis?

starbursting.title: Starbursting
starbursting.context: Starbursting is a creative brainstorming technique that generates questions rather than answers. By systematically asking Who, What, When, Where, Why, and How questions about a topic, starbursting helps uncover gaps in understanding, identify research needs, and ensure comprehensive analysis. This technique, developed as part of creative problem-solving methodologies, is particularly valuable in early stages of planning and analysis.
goodUseCases: Gap analysis and information needs assessment
notIdealFor: Problems where questions are already well-defined
Situations requiring immediate answers rather than questions

causeway.title: Causeway Analysis
causeway.description: 6-stage structured COG methodology: Identify threats, map critical capabilities/requirements, and determine leverage points for influence operations
causeway.context: Causeway Analysis uses the PUTAR methodology (Problem, Undesired Actor, Target Audience, Remedy, Story) to analyze threats and develop influence operations strategies. This framework systematically identifies critical capabilities, requirements, and proximate targets that can be influenced to counter adversary actions. Developed for military information operations, Causeway provides a structured approach to understanding and disrupting adversary capabilities.
goodUseCases: Strategic competition and gray zone operations

threat_id.label: Threat Identification
threat_id.description: Define the issue and location being analyzed

problem.label: Problem (P)
problem.description: What is the specific problem or threat behavior?

undesired_actor.label: Undesired Actor (U)
undesired_actor.description: Who is the adversary or actor of responsibility causing this problem?

target_audience.label: Target Audience (TA)
target_audience.description: What audiences can be influenced to counter this threat?

remedy.label: Remedy (R)
remedy.description: What is the desired end state or solution?

story.label: Story (S)
story.description: What narrative or messaging supports the remedy?

critical_capabilities.label: Critical Capabilities
critical_capabilities.description: What capabilities enable the undesired actor to execute the threat?

critical_requirements.label: Critical Requirements
critical_requirements.description: What essential conditions, resources, or dependencies support these capabilities?

proximate_targets.label: Proximate Targets
proximate_targets.description: What tangible entities can be influenced or targeted to disrupt critical requirements?

surveillance.title: Surveillance Framework (ISR Collection Planning)
surveillance.description: Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance operations planning based on RAND Strategies-to-Tasks methodology
surveillance.context: The Surveillance Framework, based on RAND's Strategies-to-Tasks methodology, provides a systematic approach to planning and executing Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) operations. It links collection targets to operational tasks, objectives, and commander's guidance with relative utilities. This framework enables intelligence officers to rapidly analyze costs and benefits of ISR collection strategies, prioritize competing tasks, and allow flexible real-time changes to plans. ISR is the coordinated and integrated acquisition, processing, and provision of timely, accurate, relevant, coherent information to support commanders' conduct of activities.
goodUseCases: Military ISR operations planning and execution
Real-time ISR retasking for emerging targets
notIdealFor: Strategic policy analysis without operational focus
Pure analytical problems without collection component
Analysis where collection assets are unavailable

commanders_guidance.label: Commander's Guidance
commanders_guidance.description: Top-level strategic objectives and operational priorities

intelligence_requirements.label: Intelligence Requirements
intelligence_requirements.description: Priority Intelligence Requirements (PIRs) and Essential Elements of Information (EEIs)

collection_strategies.label: Collection Strategies
collection_strategies.description: Methods, platforms, and approaches for information gathering

surveillance_targets.label: Surveillance Targets
surveillance_targets.description: Entities, locations, or activities requiring persistent monitoring

reconnaissance_tasks.label: Reconnaissance Tasks
reconnaissance_tasks.description: Specific information-gathering missions to answer intelligence questions

collection_assets.label: Collection Assets
collection_assets.description: Available sensors, platforms, and resources for ISR operations

fundamental-flow.title: Fundamental Flow Analysis
fundamental-flow.description: Intelligence cycle and information flow analysis for process optimization
fundamental-flow.context: Fundamental Flow Analysis examines the intelligence cycle and information flow through all stages: Planning & Direction, Collection, Processing, Exploitation & Production, Dissemination, and Feedback. This framework identifies bottlenecks, measures efficiency, and optimizes the flow of information from raw data to finished intelligence. By mapping complete information paths and measuring timeliness, accuracy, and relevance at each stage, organizations can improve intelligence production processes, reduce delays, and enhance the value delivered to consumers. This framework is essential for intelligence process improvement and optimization initiatives.
goodUseCases: Quality assurance and process maturity evaluation
notIdealFor: Situations where process improvement is not the focus

collection.label: Collection
collection.description: Information gathering from various sources and methods

processing.label: Processing
processing.description: Converting raw data into usable formats and structures

dissemination.label: Dissemination
dissemination.description: Distribution of intelligence to consumers and stakeholders

feedback_evaluation.label: Feedback & Evaluation
feedback_evaluation.description: Assessment of intelligence value and process effectiveness

information_sources.label: Information Sources
information_sources.description: Catalog of available information feeds and collection capabilities

flow_metrics.label: Flow Metrics
flow_metrics.description: Timeliness, accuracy, relevance, and efficiency measurements
